clusters.title: Will UK taxpayers get their £122m back from PPE Medpro?
clusters.neutral_headline: UK taxpayers may not get £122m back from PPE Medpro

items.title: Will UK taxpayers get their £122m back from PPE Medpro?
items.standfirst: The high court told the company linked to Michelle Mone to pay up over the supply of defective gowns, but there appears no clear route to reclaim the fundsThe five-year unravelling of Britain’s most high-profile Covid contracts scandal involving a baroness, her husband and multimillion-pound government deals accelerated last week with a high court judgment against the company linked to the former Tory peer Michelle Mone.The judge, Mrs Justice Cockerill, ruled that PPE Medpro, owned by Mone’s husband, the Isle of Man-based businessman Doug Barrowman, supplied defective personal protective equipment (PPE) for use in the NHS during the pandemic. Cockerill ordered that PPE Medpro must return the sum of £122m, which the Department of Health and Social Care paid for the order of 25m sterile surgical gowns, under a contract awarded in June 2020 via the VIP lane. Continue reading...
items.content: The high court told the company linked to Michelle Mone to pay up over the supply of defective gowns, but there appears no clear route to reclaim the fundsThe five-year unravelling of Britain’s most high-profile Covid contracts scandal involving a baroness, her husband and multimillion-pound government deals accelerated last week with a high court judgment against the company linked to the former Tory peer Michelle Mone.The judge, Mrs Justice Cockerill, ruled that PPE Medpro, owned by Mone’s husband, the Isle of Man-based businessman Doug Barrowman, supplied defective personal protective equipment (PPE) for use in the NHS during the pandemic. Cockerill ordered that PPE Medpro must return the sum of £122m, which the Department of Health and Social Care paid for the order of 25m sterile surgical gowns, under a contract awarded in June 2020 via the VIP lane. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A court ordered PPE Medpro to repay £122 million.
The company supplied defective PPE during the pandemic.
The funds were paid by the Department of Health and Social Care.
The contract was awarded via a VIP lane in June 2020.
There is no clear path to reclaim the funds for taxpayers.

clusters.title: TikTok influencers fuelling parallel market for unlicensed weight-loss drug
clusters.neutral_headline: TikTok influencers fuel market for unlicensed weight-loss drug

items.title: TikTok influencers fuelling parallel market for unlicensed weight-loss drug
items.standfirst: Guardian finds a thriving trade on Telegram for retatrutide, which is still in clinical trials and illegal to sellAn online parallel market for an unlicensed weight-loss drug is being fuelled by TikTok fitness influencers and sellers on WhatsApp, a Guardian investigation can reveal.Retatrutide, which is still in clinical trials, is being advertised by social media influencers for its supposed fat-burning effects. Followers are urged to message the accounts privately for supplier links, as well as being provided with discount codes. Continue reading...
items.content: Guardian finds a thriving trade on Telegram for retatrutide, which is still in clinical trials and illegal to sellAn online parallel market for an unlicensed weight-loss drug is being fuelled by TikTok fitness influencers and sellers on WhatsApp, a Guardian investigation can reveal.Retatrutide, which is still in clinical trials, is being advertised by social media influencers for its supposed fat-burning effects. Followers are urged to message the accounts privately for supplier links, as well as being provided with discount codes. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A thriving online market exists for the unlicensed drug retatrutide.
TikTok influencers promote retatrutide for weight loss.
The drug is still in clinical trials and illegal to sell.
Sellers use WhatsApp and provide discount codes.
The Guardian investigation revealed the online market's existence.

clusters.title: Maureen Crill obituary
clusters.neutral_headline: Maureen Crill obituary: Nurse, midwife, health manager

items.title: Maureen Crill obituary
items.standfirst: My wife, Maureen Crill, who has died aged 68 from complications of a rare autoimmune disease, was a nurse, midwife and health manager who spent most of her working life on challenging humanitarian postings in Africa, South America, Asia and the tip of North America.Practical, tough, down-to-earth and brave, she had great resilience, and her cool nerve marked her out for the demanding work she carried out, often in areas of armed conflict. In every setting her courage, simple kindness, professionalism and cultural sensitivity earned her respect and acceptance. Continue reading...
items.content: My wife, Maureen Crill, who has died aged 68 from complications of a rare autoimmune disease, was a nurse, midwife and health manager who spent most of her working life on challenging humanitarian postings in Africa, South America, Asia and the tip of North America.Practical, tough, down-to-earth and brave, she had great resilience, and her cool nerve marked her out for the demanding work she carried out, often in areas of armed conflict. In every setting her courage, simple kindness, professionalism and cultural sensitivity earned her respect and acceptance. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Maureen Crill, who died at 68, was a nurse, midwife, and health manager.
She worked in challenging humanitarian postings in various countries.
Crill was known for her resilience and cool nerve.
She displayed courage, kindness, and cultural sensitivity.
Her work often took place in areas of armed conflict.

clusters.title: Enjoying my meat that’s low on miles | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Meat and vegetables contribute to increased CO2 levels

items.title: Enjoying my meat that’s low on miles | Letter
items.standfirst: It’s good to encourage people to reduce their intake of meat and eat more vegetables, but these also contribute to increased CO2 levels, says Dr Kirstine OswaldI’m glad that the impact of ultra‑processed food on the climate is being investigated. Not only is it bad for our health but it also requires ingredients to be transported around the world (The hidden cost of ultra-processed foods on the environment: ‘The whole industry should pay’, theguardian.com, 8 October).Meat and dairy are often singled out as foods detrimental to the environment. While it’s laudable to encourage people to reduce their intake of animal-based foods and eat more vegetables, nuts and grains, many of these have also to be transported great distances and so contribute to increased CO2 levels. Continue reading...
items.content: It’s good to encourage people to reduce their intake of meat and eat more vegetables, but these also contribute to increased CO2 levels, says Dr Kirstine OswaldI’m glad that the impact of ultra‑processed food on the climate is being investigated. Not only is it bad for our health but it also requires ingredients to be transported around the world (The hidden cost of ultra-processed foods on the environment: ‘The whole industry should pay’, theguardian.com, 8 October).Meat and dairy are often singled out as foods detrimental to the environment. While it’s laudable to encourage people to reduce their intake of animal-based foods and eat more vegetables, nuts and grains, many of these have also to be transported great distances and so contribute to increased CO2 levels. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The impact of ultra-processed food on the environment is being investigated.
Meat and dairy are often singled out as detrimental to the environment.
Vegetables, nuts, and grains also contribute to CO2 levels.
Many of these foods are transported long distances.
The article discusses the environmental impact of food transportation.

clusters.title: Down on the farm with George Clooney | Brief letters
clusters.neutral_headline: George Clooney discusses survival skills on his farm

items.title: Down on the farm with George Clooney | Brief letters
items.standfirst: Survival skills | Poking Paddington | Counting roadworks | Thelonious Monk | Harry KaneGeorge Clooney says of his children: “It’s important to me that they can survive,” and invites them to watch his handyman skills around their farm in France, including “fixing … the automated cover for the swimming pool” (Report, 7 October). It strikes me that he and I live in different worlds, with very different definitions both of “survival” and of “farm”.Fiona CollinsCarrog, Sir Ddinbych• Like Gillian Greenfield (Letters, 8 October), I used to put the radio on when I couldn’t sleep and often fell asleep to LBC News. Because of its traffic reports, I woke up fully apprised of the progress of the roadworks on Brent Cross flyover.Mark RedheadOxford Continue reading...
items.content: Survival skills | Poking Paddington | Counting roadworks | Thelonious Monk | Harry KaneGeorge Clooney says of his children: “It’s important to me that they can survive,” and invites them to watch his handyman skills around their farm in France, including “fixing … the automated cover for the swimming pool” (Report, 7 October). It strikes me that he and I live in different worlds, with very different definitions both of “survival” and of “farm”.Fiona CollinsCarrog, Sir Ddinbych• Like Gillian Greenfield (Letters, 8 October), I used to put the radio on when I couldn’t sleep and often fell asleep to LBC News. Because of its traffic reports, I woke up fully apprised of the progress of the roadworks on Brent Cross flyover.Mark RedheadOxford Continue reading...

ai_summary: George Clooney discusses survival skills with his children.
He invites them to watch him fix his pool cover.
The author notes different definitions of "survival" and "farm".
Another letter writer discusses roadworks on the Brent Cross flyover.
One letter writer used to fall asleep to LBC News.

clusters.title: Millions of over-50s have undiagnosed sight and hearing problems, UK study suggests
clusters.neutral_headline: Millions over 50 have undiagnosed sight and hearing problems

items.title: Millions of over-50s have undiagnosed sight and hearing problems, UK study suggests
items.standfirst: Research finds significant ‘unmet need’ for help with sight and hearing health with many people unaware of problemsMillions of people aged 50 or over in the UK have undiagnosed sight or hearing problems, according to research, prompting calls for that age group to have checkups more regularly.Doctors involved in the research said the findings were “deeply concerning” and warned that those affected were at risk of falls, mental ill-health and of leading socially restricted lives.6.7 million people in the UK aged 50 or over have trouble seeing out of one or both eyes.2.4 million are visually impaired in one eye20.3 million have some form of hearing loss in one or both ears.7.7 million cannot hear clearly with both ears. Continue reading...
items.content: Research finds significant ‘unmet need’ for help with sight and hearing health with many people unaware of problemsMillions of people aged 50 or over in the UK have undiagnosed sight or hearing problems, according to research, prompting calls for that age group to have checkups more regularly.Doctors involved in the research said the findings were “deeply concerning” and warned that those affected were at risk of falls, mental ill-health and of leading socially restricted lives.6.7 million people in the UK aged 50 or over have trouble seeing out of one or both eyes.2.4 million are visually impaired in one eye20.3 million have some form of hearing loss in one or both ears.7.7 million cannot hear clearly with both ears. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Research shows millions over 50 have undiagnosed sight problems.
The research also reveals undiagnosed hearing problems in the UK.
Doctors are concerned about the "unmet need" for help.
Those affected are at risk of falls and mental ill-health.
6.7 million have trouble seeing out of one or both eyes.
